historicalFigures.name: Hammurabi
historicalFigures.background: Hammurabi was the sixth king of the First Babylonian Dynasty. He conquered Mesopotamia and is best known for issuing the Code of Hammurabi, one of the earliest legal codes.
keyDecisions: Promoting Marduk as the supreme god.
achievements: The Code of Hammurabi ('Eye for an eye').
historicalFigures.legacy: Hammurabi is the father of law. His code influenced legal systems for millennia.
quotes: To bring about the rule of righteousness in the land.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His stele is in the Louvre. He is a symbol of justice.
modernInterpretations: His laws are seen as harsh but fair for the time.

historicalFigures.name: Saddam Hussein
historicalFigures.background: Saddam Hussein was the President of Iraq from 1979 to 2003. A leading member of the Ba'ath Party, he ruled with an iron fist, leading Iraq into wars with Iran and Kuwait.
historicalFigures.legacy: Saddam is a polarizing figure. To some, a hero of Arab nationalism; to most, a brutal tyrant.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His fall marked the end of an era. His execution was a global event.
modernInterpretations: Some look back with nostalgia due to current chaos.

historicalFigures.name: Saladin
historicalFigures.nativeName: An-Nasir Salah ad-Din Yusuf ibn Ayyub
historicalFigures.background: Saladin was a Kurdish Muslim sultan who founded the Ayyubid dynasty. He recaptured Jerusalem from the Crusaders in 1187 and is renowned for his chivalry.
keyDecisions: Unifying the Muslim world (Egypt and Syria).
Making peace with Richard the Lionheart.
historicalFigures.legacy: Saladin is the ultimate hero of the Islamic world. Even his enemies admired him.
quotes: I warn you against shedding blood.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a symbol of Muslim unity and honor. Born in Tikrit.
modernInterpretations: His example is cited in peace and war.

historicalFigures.name: Nebuchadnezzar II
historicalFigures.background: Nebuchadnezzar II was the greatest king of the Neo-Babylonian Empire. He built the Hanging Gardens of Babylon and destroyed the First Temple in Jerusalem.
historicalFigures.legacy: Nebuchadnezzar is the archetype of the powerful king. Babylon became the center of the world under him.
quotes: Is this not Babylon the Great?
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a major figure in the Bible and history. Saddam Hussein compared himself to him.

historicalFigures.name: Zaha Hadid
historicalFigures.background: Zaha Hadid was an Iraqi-British architect. She was the first woman to receive the Pritzker Architecture Prize. Her futuristic designs earned her the nickname 'Queen of the Curve'.
keyDecisions: Studying at the AA in London.
Breaking the glass ceiling in architecture.
achievements: Dame Commander of the British Empire.
historicalFigures.legacy: Zaha Hadid changed the skyline of the world. She proved that impossible shapes could be built.
quotes: There are 360 degrees, so why stick to one?
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Her buildings are landmarks. She is a role model for women.

historicalFigures.name: Gilgamesh
historicalFigures.background: Gilgamesh was the semi-mythical King of Uruk. He is the protagonist of the Epic of Gilgamesh, the oldest surviving great work of literature.
keyDecisions: Going on a quest for immortality.
historicalFigures.legacy: Gilgamesh is the first hero. His story explores the human condition.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: The Epic of Gilgamesh is the foundation of literature.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a metaphor for the human search for meaning.

historicalFigures.name: Al-Mutanabbi
historicalFigures.nativeName: Abu at-Tayyib Ahmad ibn al-Husayn al-Mutanabbi
historicalFigures.background: Al-Mutanabbi is considered the greatest poet of the Arabic language. Born in Kufa, his poetry is known for its wisdom, pride, and mastery of the language.
keyDecisions: Serving the Hamdanid court in Aleppo.
historicalFigures.legacy: Al-Mutanabbi is the Shakespeare of the Arabs. His verses are proverbs today.
quotes: The horses, the night, and the desert know me.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Al-Mutanabbi Street in Baghdad is the center of book selling.

historicalFigures.name: Faisal I
historicalFigures.background: Faisal I was the first King of Iraq. A leader of the Arab Revolt during WWI (with Lawrence of Arabia), he tried to build a unified Arab state but was installed by the British in Iraq.
keyDecisions: Balancing British interests and Arab nationalism.
achievements: Founder of the Kingdom of Iraq.
historicalFigures.legacy: Faisal is the father of modern Iraq. He famously said, 'There is no Iraqi people yet'.
quotes: I have a heart full of sadness.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a tragic figure of the post-WWI era.

historicalFigures.name: Ashurbanipal
historicalFigures.background: Ashurbanipal was the last great King of the Neo-Assyrian Empire. He is famous for his library at Nineveh, which preserved the Epic of Gilgamesh.
achievements: Ruled the largest empire of his time.
challenges: The fall of Assyria shortly after his death.
historicalFigures.legacy: Ashurbanipal gave us the history of Mesopotamia. His library is the key to understanding the ancient world.
quotes: I, Ashurbanipal, learned the wisdom of Nabu.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: The British Museum holds his library. He is the symbol of Assyrian power.
modernInterpretations: His cruelty in war is also noted.

historicalFigures.name: Nuri al-Said
historicalFigures.background: Nuri al-Said was a dominant figure in Iraqi politics under the monarchy, serving as Prime Minister 14 times. He was pro-British and was brutally killed in the 1958 revolution.
achievements: Built the modern Iraqi state structure.
historicalFigures.legacy: Nuri al-Said represents the old order. His death marked the end of the monarchy and the start of the republic.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a controversial figure, seen as a traitor by nationalists but a pragmatist by historians.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a competent but out-of-touch leader.
His brutal death is a warning.

historicalFigures.name: Al-Kindi
historicalFigures.nativeName: Abu Yusuf Ya'qub ibn Ishaq as-Sabbah al-Kindi
historicalFigures.background: Al-Kindi was the first of the Islamic Peripatetic philosophers and is known as the 'Father of Arab Philosophy'. He worked in the House of Wisdom in Baghdad.
keyDecisions: Introducing Indian numerals to the Arab world.
historicalFigures.legacy: Al-Kindi started the Golden Age of Islamic philosophy. He proved that faith and reason could coexist.
quotes: We ought not to be ashamed of appreciating the truth.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He laid the groundwork for Avicenna and Averroes.
modernInterpretations: His work on code-breaking is still relevant.

historicalFigures.name: Sargon of Akkad
historicalFigures.background: Sargon of Akkad was the first ruler of the Akkadian Empire, known for his conquests of the Sumerian city-states. He created the world's first empire.
keyDecisions: Installing his daughter Enheduanna as High Priestess.
achievements: Legendary birth story (basket in the river).
historicalFigures.legacy: Sargon is the model for all future emperors. He set the standard for kingship.
quotes: I am Sargon, the great king.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His legend influenced the story of Moses.

historicalFigures.name: Enheduanna
historicalFigures.background: Enheduanna was the High Priestess of the moon god Nanna in Ur and the daughter of Sargon of Akkad. She is the first known author in history.
historicalFigures.legacy: Enheduanna is the mother of literature. She proved that women held high office in ancient Iraq.
quotes: My king, something has been created that no one has created before.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a feminist icon. Her hymns were used for centuries.
modernInterpretations: Her existence is proven by archaeology.

historicalFigures.name: Abd al-Karim Qasim
historicalFigures.background: Abd al-Karim Qasim was a brigadier general who led the 1958 revolution that overthrew the Iraqi monarchy. He became the first Prime Minister of the Republic.
historicalFigures.legacy: Qasim is remembered as 'The Sole Leader'. He is popular among the poor but hated by pan-Arabists.
quotes: I am the son of the people.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His image is often displayed in Baghdad taxis.
modernInterpretations: His execution was televised, shocking the nation.

historicalFigures.name: Jalal Talabani
historicalFigures.background: Jalal Talabani was a Kurdish leader and the President of Iraq from 2005 to 2014. He was the first non-Arab president of an Arab state.
keyDecisions: Accepting the presidency of a unified Iraq.
historicalFigures.legacy: Talabani is the father of the new Iraq. He was a unifying figure in a divided land.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is respected by Kurds and Arabs alike.
modernInterpretations: His humor and diplomacy are missed.

historicalFigures.name: Gertrude Bell
historicalFigures.background: Gertrude Bell was a British writer, traveller, and political officer. She played a major role in establishing the modern state of Iraq and founded the Iraq Museum.
challenges: Being a woman in a man's world.
historicalFigures.legacy: Bell created Iraq. Her museum preserved its history until the 2003 looting.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a controversial but essential figure.

historicalFigures.name: Al-Jahiz
historicalFigures.nativeName: Abu Uthman Amr ibn Bahr al-Kinani al-Basri (Al-Jahiz)
historicalFigures.background: Al-Jahiz was an Arab prose writer and theologian. He wrote the 'Book of Animals', which contains early ideas on evolution.
keyDecisions: Living in the House of Wisdom.
Dying under a pile of books (legend).
historicalFigures.legacy: Al-Jahiz is a giant of literature. His wit and wisdom are timeless.
quotes: The book is a silent talker.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the master of Arabic style.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a precursor to Darwin.

historicalFigures.name: Kadhim Al-Sahir
historicalFigures.background: Kadhim Al-Sahir is a singer and composer, known as the 'Caesar of Arabic Song'. He popularized Iraqi maqam and sings the poems of Nizar Qabbani.
keyDecisions: Refusing to sing for Saddam (later years).
historicalFigures.legacy: Kadhim is the voice of romance and Iraq. He brings beauty to a war-torn image.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the most famous living Iraqi artist.
